Temperature: Temperature increases as the level of greenhouse effect increases.  Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.
CO2: Atmospheric CO2 increase is the forcer in this scenario.  CO2 increase results in a higher level of the greenhouse effect.
Volcano: Volcanoes, Mountains, and Isolation are not affected by a change in CO2. They are likely not to change over the 10 MY time scale of this simulation.
Ice: Rising temperatures will melt ice, but response time is longer than 200 years
Sea: Rising temperature raises sea level quickly. Melting glacial ice and volcanic activity also raise sea level, but response times are longer.
Weathering C Burial: Rising temperature raises evaporation and precipitation, which increases weathering rates.
CO3 Desposition: Rising weathering rates increase carbonate deposition, but response times are long (~100,000 years)
Sediment: Rising precipitation transports and deposits more sediment, but carbon burial response times are long
Weathering C Release: Rising weathering rates can release buried carbon (if carbon-bearing rocks reside at the surface), but response times are long

Temperature: Temperature increases as the level of greenhouse effect increases.  Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.
CO2: Atmospheric CO2 increase is the forcer in this scenario.  CO2 increase results in a higher level of the greenhouse effect.
Ice: Rising temperatures will melt ice, but response time shorter than this time scale.
Sea: Rising temperature and Melting glacial ice raises sea level in this time scale.  Volcanic activity also raise sea level, but it is constant in this scenario.
Weathering C Burial: Rising temperature raises evaporation and precipitation, which increases weathering rates.
CO3 Desposition: Rising weathering rates increase carbonate deposition, but response times are ~100,000 years
Sediment: Although C burial due to sediments and release of C due to weathering probably change, they are likely to be minor.

Temperature: Temperature increases as the level of greenhouse effect increases.  Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.
CO2: Atmospheric CO2 increase is the forcer in this scenario.  CO2 increase results in a higher level of the greenhouse effect.
Ice: Rising temperatures will melt ice, but response time shorter than this time scale.
Sea: Rising temperature and Melting glacial ice raises sea level in this time scale.  Volcanic activity also raise sea level, but it is constant in this scenario.
Weathering C Burial: Rising temperature raises evaporation and precipitation, which increases weathering rates.
CO3 Desposition: Rising weathering rates increase carbonate deposition;  response times are ~100,000 years

Temperature: Temperature increases as the level of greenhouse effect increases.  Since CO2 level remained constant during this period, temperature also remained constant.
CO2: CO2 has arrived at equilibrium, with carbon sinks (in this case carbonate deposition is the sink that changed) coming to equal the rise of atmospheric CO2.
Ice: Since temperature stayed constant, ice level will stay constant too.
Sea: Because ice level and temperature stabilized during this time period, sea level also remains constant.
Weathering C Burial: Rising temperature raises evaporation and precipitation, which increases weathering rates.  Since temperature remained constant, so did weathering.
CO3 Desposition: Since weathering rate remained constant, carbonate deposition also remained constant during this time period.
